Award.AwardTitle: Three-Dimensional Characterization of a Pseudotachylyte-Bearing Fault
Award.AbstractNarration: Fault slip is the dominant mode of deformation in the earth's upper crust. Faults within the crust, however, exhibit a range of behavior, from earthquake-generating stick-slip to aseismic creep. Laboratory-derived friction laws can explain this spectrum of fault behavior; however, the scaling of these laws to the conditions of natural earthquakes and the interpretation of the laws' physical meanings have proven to be formidable challenges. This research will bridge laboratory and earthquake scales by imaging the three dimensional geometry of pseudotachylyte-bearing faults. Pseudotachylytes, fault rocks formed from frictional melts, are generally considered the only unequivocal evidence ofearthquake slip velocities preserved in fault zones. The solidification of frictional melt "freezes in" earthquake source geometries; however, it also precludes the development of extensive fault surface exposures that have enabled previous studies of fault zone geometry. We have overcome this difficulty by imaging the intact 3D geometry of the fault using high-resolution X-ray computed tomography (CT). In this study we will use CT imagery of natural and experimental fault surfaces to quantify surface roughness, frictional contact area, and pseudotachylyte thickness and will thus determine the evolution of fault roughness with slip and estimate key frictional parameters at earthquake nucleation and propagation scales. The proposed project will improve the understanding of earthquakes and their effects, one of the primary goals of the National Earthquake Hazard Reduction Program. Furthermore, the project will establish a new collaboration between Wesleyan University, a primarily undergraduate institution in the US, and scientists from the Istituto Nazionale di Geofisica e Vulcanologia (INGV), a world-renowned research institute in Italy. Undergraduate students will play an integral role in the project, planting the seeds for future international and interdisciplinary research into the processes of brittle deformation in the earth's crust. These students will experience the full scope of the scientific process, from hypothesis generation, to study design, to presentation of results at professional meetings and in a written thesis. The project is being supported by the EAR Tectonics Program and the Office of International Science and Engineering's Global Venture Fund.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

Large damaging earthquakes typically initiate on faults 6-9 miles (10-15 km) below the earth’s surface, a depth that has rarely been reached through drilling. In order to directly investigate rocks from the earthquake source region, we thus rely on the study of ancient faults, uplifted from depth and exposed at the surface through erosion. When studying these ancient faults, pseudotachylyte (dark glassy rock formed from solidified frictional melt) is the clearest evidence of ancient earthquake slip.

In this study we used advanced imaging technologies to characterize the three-dimensional geometry of pseudotachylyte-bearing faults from the Gole Larghe fault zone exposed in the Italian Alps. This fault has become one of the premier sites for studying pseudotachylyte and earthquake processes. We collected rock cores from the fault, scanned them using x-ray computed tomography (similar to medical CT imaging) and then separated out the portion of the resulting 3D image volumes that corresponds with the pseudotachylyte. Our goal has been to characterize the shape of the fault zones in order to better understand the physical changes that occur during an earthquake.

Our results reveal that the surfaces of pseudotachylyte-bearing faults exhibit a distinctive geometry associated with melting of individual minerals rather than the equilibrium melting that is typical of melting in most geologic environments. This texture is found on fault surfaces with as little as ~35 mm of slip, suggesting that melting, and possibly melt lubrication of faults, occurs after very little slip. In contrast, surfaces of pseudotachylyte injection veins (cracks filled with solidified melt that has been squeezed off of the fault surfaces) do not display this texture. Injection veins thus record processes of melt flow, cooling, and solidification, but not melting. 

 

Intellectual Merit

The work from this project helps to better constrain the physical conditions and active processes in the earthquake source region, which are important for improving models of earthquake initiation, slip, and stopping. The work will also help connect results from laboratory experiments to natural faults.

 

Broader Impacts

The proposed project is helping to improve our understanding of earthquake processes, one of the primary goals of the National Earthquake Hazard Reduction Program (NEHRP).

Results have been and will continue to be shared in public science talks on faults and earthquakes.

Undergraduate students played an integral role in the project, planting the seeds for future international interdisciplinary research into earthquake science.  Three students experienced the full scientific process from hypothesis generation, to study design, to presentation of results at professional meetings and in written reports.
